data.title: The True South
data.text: This is America's history at its best. This house is truly a a historic treasure. Do not miss it on a visit to Macon.  It is not a visit for young family but is wonderful for couples of any age.

data.title: The Pearl of the South
data.text: Great tour of a great house of the Italanian renaissance.  Hopefully you can get Sarah Hall as your docent. She is very good.  If you are into touring antebellum houses, this is a must, since it is so different. So richly adorned. So big.  This was a house of several very wealthy people and they put a lot of money into it.

data.title: Downton Abbey of Macon
data.text: We bicycled up the steep hill and saw the beautiful fountain and small garden area.  The tour allows you to witness beautiful artwork, exceptional architecture, and period furnishings.  The tour was guided by the most enchanting and knowledgeable host - we truly felt as though we were guests.  Not to be missed - spring for the additional nominal fee to tour the top of the house, and you will be treated to an outside selfie of the cupola.  Being afraid of heights, I settled for the views safely inside the cupola.

data.title: Stunning!
data.text: The tour of Georgia Trust for Historic Preservation"s, Johnson-Felton-Hay House is not to be missed. This four plus level Italianate mansion is stunning, the docents are informed and approachable, and the tales of the families who have lived here make each room come to life. If the extended tours or behind the scenes tours are offered, they are worth your time to learn even more about the home, the families, and the time periods. The house is being meticulously restored with more work completed each year, so even if you have toured in the past, there is more to see.

data.title: One of the BEST restored houses I have been through!
data.text: This house is not to be missed.  I have been to Newport, Charleston, Savannah, and loved them all but this house spared by the Sherman march to the sea, is a true wonder.  It is also a bargain compared to most restored homes.  I loved the tour and then paid an extra $4 to explore all seven floors and the cupola on top.  It was more than worth it.  Great tour of an amazing residence truly a work of art in itself.  The Hay House is worth a trip to Macon just for itself.

data.title: Don't Miss this Beauty!
data.text: The quality and beauty of this historic home will amaze any visitor no matter how well traveled. This house ranks as one of treasures of the US and should not be missed by anyone with an interest in architecture or design. I visited on a quiet Monday morning and had a private tour with a lovely informative docent. Well worth the price of admission.

data.title: Awesome
data.text: We ended up in Macon trying to stay away from Hurricane Matthew and had no idea what there was to see in Macon. Saw the Hay House on TripAdvisor and went to have a look. The house was amazing to tour and I highly recommend it. Tom, the guide, was fantastic. We paid the extra $4 to go right up into the cupola and it was well worth the extra $$. Tom really knew the house and it's history and was also really helpful with suggestions for other things to see and do in Macon and the surrounding area.

data.title: Took the tour, worth the time, effort, and expense
data.text:
I thought this place was amazing.  I never saw any rudeness from a single staff person.  I'm from the north too!  Maybe I didn't see any rudeness because I was pleasant to the staff, and was treated pleasantly.  Maybe it's because there's not been a "north vs. south" mentality in several decades.  You decide.

If you're into these things, request the advanced, or private tour (Can't remember what it's called), and you get to see a lot more.  But, yes, tours are scheduled, and only the privileged would think that a tour can start anytime they show up simply because they are there.

I am in awe of the restoration efforts underway, and plan on coming back from time to time to see how it progresses.

data.title: Amazing propertn.
data.text: When built it was ahead of its time with hot and cold running water a ventilation system and speaking tubes. Our guide Sara was excellent really bringing the house and its history to life, well,worth paying extra to see the top floors and the cupola with great views over the town.

data.title: Gorgeous historic home
data.text: We thoroughly enjoyed seeing this grand historic home. It has some really unique features that we enjoyed seeing: curved pocket doors, use of natural light, the way it was built to stay cool without air conditioning, etc. We paid the extra $5 to see the attic and the widow's walk and really were glad that we did. The docents were really nice and we enjoyed meeting both of them. They were very knowledgeable and had a lot of love for the house. We own a historic mansion that we did a meticulous renovation on so we really appreciate the time and effort it takes to restore a place like this. Thank you for a wonderful visit!

data.title: Hay House stands proud
data.text: Hay House makes a stand on 934 Georgia Ave.  Its setting is magnificent if you approach the house down from the river and up to the house higher up. The house is beautifully preserved. The young guides are extremely well informed, warm and friendly, in fact real young Southern belles! The architecture and functional design of the house are astounding as much still makes practical sense today such as the wine cellar cooling system. If you love the antebellum period and its architecture, this is a must see.

data.title: Spectacular
data.text: I was enthralled and in awe of the "Hay House", we had an exceptional guided tour with (Elliot Fernandez)  the mansion was breathtakingly beautiful and so well preserved....A must see!!!

data.title: "Palace of the South"
data.text: From the instant I saw the Johnston-Felton-Hay House in Macon, Georgia, I was reminded of Longwood, the majestic and magnificent but unfinished antebellum mansion in Natchez, Mississippi. Located at 934 Georgia Avenue, atop Coleman Hill in downtown Macon, the Hay House is an 18,000-square-foot, 24-room palace that was designed by New York architect T. Thomas and Son and built in part by craftsmen and artisans brought from Italy. Built between 1855 and 1859 by William Butler Johnston, who obtained his wealth by investing in banks, railroads and public utilities rather than cotton, the house is built in the Italian Renaissance Revival style and includes four levels crowned by a three-story cupola. Often described as the "Palace of the South," it was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1973 for its architectural uniqueness. Its technological amenities were unsurpassed in the mid-19th century--hot and cold running water, central heating, a speaker-tube system connecting 15 rooms, an 8,000-gallon water tank, a French lift equivalent to today's elevator, an in-house kitchen and an elaborate ventilation system. Two families lives in the house, the first over four generations. But most of today's furnishings date from the Hay family's occupancy from 1926 to 1962. A few pieces date to the Johnston family (1860 to 1896), most notably the Eastlake-style dining room suite, which includes the 1857 marble statue, "Ruth Gleaning," by American expatriate sculptor Randolph Rogers. After Mrs. Johnston died in 1896, her daughter Mary Ellen and her husband, Judge William H. Felton, lived in the house until 1926. They remodeled and redecorated parts of the house, updated the plumbing and added electricity. After the deaths of the Feltons, the house was sold to Parks Lee Hay and his wife. They redecorated the entire house, updating it to fit the new 20th century decor. In 1977, the ownership and operation of the house was formally transferred to The Georgia Trust for Historic Preservation. Today, it is open for daily tours and renovations continue to keep Hay House up to date.

data.title: Exquiste display of the wealthy past
data.text: The 500 pound front door will amaze you because they are so easy to open. The grand ball room was astounding. This is a must see.

data.title: Unique National Historic Landmark
data.text: Although we have lived in Macon for several years, we had never visited the Hay House until this past weekend.   My husband and I took my mother-in-law and our 9 year old.  We were on the last tour of the day (3:00 p.m.)   Amazed by the advanced use of technology for its time is an understatement.   This house was more advanced than the White House.  It is a beautiful interpretation of the three eras of owners who lived there until it was opened to the public.  Although it is still under going renovation,  three of the seven floors are magnificent.   If you decide to take the tour up to the cupola,  just know that as of 2016, you will only see an attic room, a view of the lead lined water cistern,  and a pretty but very narrow staircase on your way up.  Only about two people can fit in the upper cupola at a time.  The view of Macon is nice, but if the weather is hot outside,  it will be hotter up top, so be prepared.  The tour of the cupola is $4 extra per person.  In my humble opinion,  I suggest waiting on that part of the tour until more had been completed.   But the rest of the tour is most definitely worth it.

data.title: Surprise trip
data.text: Have never been and was a great surprise. If you like CIvil War era history, this is an interesting place. Alot of history in this place. If only the walls could talk, the stories they could tell.

data.title: Beautiful Tour Back In Time!
data.text: This home is beautiful, full of amazing features.  Unbelievable craftsmanship you definitely won't be disappointed!  A true Southern Mansion you must see!

data.title: Unique Pre-Civil War Home
data.text: Had General Sherman not been turned around by a flooded Ocmulgee River back in the day, this home and many other period mansions would likely been compromised. This is a place where history has been cherished and carefully restored to show the stories of the many families who lived here. If you have mobility problems, the stairs will be challenging but for those who are able to investigate it, it is well-worth it!
